bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, February 28, 1901

div1.p: Kean writes about his return to Cuba after a trip to the United States. Louise Kean has been active in charitable work around the Camp.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, February 28, 1901
div1.p:
I surely thought that
I would have written to you
before this especially as I
am now for the present
unattached, and theoreti-
cally a gentleman of elegant
leisure. But in point of
fact there seems to be a
lot going on. I have had
the money accounts of
the Yellow Fever Commission
to straighten out, and
Louise seems to deep in
a lot of entertainments
charitable fairs etc, etc.
2
I found the family very
well indeed but Mr. Bobs
had succeeded in trans-
ferring to his own fat
little body most of the
adipose which you and
Mausy put on to Louise
last summer & fall with
so much labor. So I at
once put Mr. Bobs on
three meals a day of
Mellins food & condensed
milk, which helps her
out considerably, and agrees
with him perfectly.

I am immensely relieved
to know that McCosh is
satisfied with George's
progress, & that his temperature
3/
have come down to normal for all day. &
I hope soon that we will be able to see him
in Cuba. But when the reaction comes
for Molly there is no telling what pranks
her nerves will play her.

I had a very jolly trip down with Miss Bacon
& Miss Brandreth Mrs. Slocums nieces, and
Capt. Adams, 5th Art. & Major Rolfe. We
nearly froze for the first 36 hours as the
Cabins had no heating arrangements.
My bottle of cocktails which I purchased
of Acker & Merrill saved five valuable
lives during this time of trial.

I enjoyed so much the few hours of my
stay with you that were not spent on
railroads and trolleys my dear Gran.
My trip was one continued hike from the
time I left here until I got back but it
was pleasant nevertheless. My only regret
is that I did not have time to run
down to Edgehill for a little visit.

All the women in the house are rushing
madly around this morning preparing
4
for the garden party at
the Arsenal this afternoon
for the benefit of the Army
widows and orphans.
Louise is on the refreshment
committee & as usual
is pulling a laboring car.

The cottage at the hospital
is finished and I suppose
we will move into it in
about a week. It has three
bed rooms, sitting room - bathroom
dining room & a detached
kitchen & servant's room.
So we really have no more
room for guests than we
have here where we, also
have three bed rooms.
There is a porch all around
and altho the arrangements
might be better in some
respects, I think we will
be very comfortable.

I shall of course begin
promptly to plant out
things and have some flowers
and some of these gorgeous
crotons.

Tell Peg that the velvet came
safely and thank her for
it. I left a suit of outing
flannel pajamas in Nease's
room - perhaps George when
he comes can bring them
down as well as the
watches. Has Caz made
his peace yet? Love to all
dear Gran from
